Rumphius1711	1	Cancer Vocans	Cattam Pangel; Roeper; Roepende Krabbe	text p. 2; plate 10: figure E	citation	Rumphius1705	1	=	=	.	This book is predominantly a reproduction of the plates from his 1705 work.
Ryoan1712	1	.	つまじろ, 望潮蟹	Volume 46, entry in lower right corner of page with crabs	location	Japan	.	>&ldquo;fiddler crabs&rdquo;	Harada1993	.	An illustrated encylopedia from 1713, volume 46 inludes a crab called &ldquo;tumajiro&rdquo; which Harada (1993) has stated might be a fiddler crab (and I can concur). The Chinese name in the entry "望潮蟹" roughly translates to "hope tide crabs" and is still used as a Chinese term for fiddler crabs today.

Yoritaka	1	.	Saku; Hashiri-kani; Nikiri-kani	figure	location	Japan	.	lactea	Yamaguchi2001.1	Female crab, originally drawn by Kurimoto Suiken. Saku = &ldquo;running crab&rdquo;; Hashiri-kani = &ldquo;running crab&rdquo;; Nikiri-kani = &ldquo;fist crab&rdquo;	A natural history manuscript edited by Matsudaira Yoritaka, with figures by many different artists. The date of completion is uncertain, but is after 1762, while Yoritaka died in 1771. Included are a few figures of the fiddler crab {{lactea}}.

Fabricius (1798) used an almost identical name as Herbst (1790) for a very different species, causing some authors to assume that the species of Fabricius was the same as the species of Herbst.	.

Suiken	1	.	Tenbo-gani; Shiomaneki	figures	location	Wakayama, Honshu, Japan	.	arcuata	<	Three different figures of male crabs. Tenbo-gani = &ldquo;one handed man crab&rdquo;; Shiomaneki = &ldquo;tide beckoning crab&rdquo;	This is the general collection of the drawings of Suiken. The dates are unknown, but much of it has to predate 1826, since figures from this collection were reproduced in the <em>Kai-ka rui siya-sin</em> which was given to Siebold in that year. Three of the four fiddler crab drawings (all {{arcuata}}) were reproduced in the later work.
Suiken	2	.	.	figure	location	Japan	.	arcuata	<	A male crab, not reproduced in the later work.	.
Suiken1826	1	Ocypode (Gelasimus)	Kometsuki-gani; Shiomaneki	plate 2: figure 11	citation	Yoritaka	1	=	=	Female crab. Kometsuki-gani = &ldquo;rice-cleaning crab&rdquo;; Shiomaneki = &ldquo;tide beckoning crab&rdquo;	This is the collection of drawings given by Suiken to Siebold in 1826. Most, if not all, of the drawings were reproductions from earlier works, some of which were by other artists. Of the five fiddler crab illustrations in this manuscript, at least four are originally by Suiken (the male {{lactea}} may not be).<p>The Japanese names are from Suiken; Latin names, when given, were added by Siebold.<p>These were used, in part, by de Haan when describing the Japanese Crustacea.

MilneEdwards1837.2	4	Gelasimus forceps	Gélasime pince	text p. 52	specimen	Australasia <!>	.	lactea	.	(Crane, 1975: p. 323) This name has been discarded. The "male" specimen turns out to be an amalgamation of a female body from one species (identifiable only to genus <em class="species">Tubuca</em>) and a claw from a male {{lactea}}. Another specimen stored nearby, labeled as &ldquo;lactea&rdquo;, turned out to be a claw from a male <em class="species">Tubuca</em> on a male {{lactea}} body. While it is likely the claws can be swapped, we still have a minimum of 3 different individuals in this mixup, including a male claw and female body, possibly, but not definitively from the same species. Ng <em>et al.</em> 2008 designated the chela as the lectotype of the name, formally making this name a junion synonym of {{lactea}}.	.

Smith1870.2	1.1	Gelasimus styliferus	.	text p. 114-115, 118-119	location	Ecuador	.	stylifera	<	.	Smith may be the first author to formally discuss splitting fiddler crabs into broad- and narrow-front groups, although he does not name them (different names are not applied to these groups until Bott 1954). He also recognizes complete distinctness between the American Atlantic and Pacific species.

SavilleKent1897	2	Gelasimus sp. {1}	.	text p. 241	location	Broome, Western Australia, Australia	.	polita	>MSR	described as &ldquo;carapace in the male bright blue centrally, with a brown anterior border. The ambulatory limbs were pale yellow, and the fighting and rudimentary chaela a most delicate rose pink&rdquo;	.
SavilleKent1897	3	Gelasimus variatus	.	text p. 241	location	Broome, Western Australia, Australia	.	dampieri	>MSR	He is uncertain if the name is correct. He describes it as &ldquo;a species nearly as large as the scarlet one, but much less abundant, having a purple carapace, lilac and ochre yellow ambulatory limbs, and a portion only of the large fighting chaela orange red&rdquo; 	.
SavilleKent1897	4	Gelasimus sp. {2}	.	text p. 241	location	Broome, Western Australia, Australia	.	mjoebergi	>MSR	described as &ldquo;the smallest species of all, having a carapace, or shell, scarcely half an inch in diameter, makes its burrows in sandy situations, far up on the beach near high spring level. Its strikingly delicate colouring included a pale lilac carapace, rose pink legs, and a large lemon-yellow fighting claw&rdquo;	.
SavilleKent1897	5	Gelasimus sp. {3}	.	text p. 240-241	location	Broome, Western Australia, Australia	.	?	.	It is not clear which species he was describing. &ldquo;One form, equal in size to the scarlet species, and, in this instance, living in its vicinity, had the large, but somewhat shorter and thicker, fighting chrela in the male cream colour, while the body and all the other limbs were a slaty black.&rdquo; 	.

Gerstaeker1901	1	Gelasimus	.	text p. 823, 837, 843-844, 847, 853, 860-861, 863-864, 867-869, 930, 942, 1036, 1051, 1063, 1108	n/a	.	0	>&ldquo;fiddler crabs&rdquo;	=	.	Throughout most of this book (up through about page 1100 or so), they refer to the genera <em class="species">Gelasimus</em> and <em class="species">&ldquo;fiddler crabs&rdquo;</em> , but only after the more formal classification at the end shift them to <em class="species">&ldquo;fiddler crabs&rdquo;</em> and <em class="species">Ucides</em> for the last 200 pages. It makes for some confusion.

Nutting1919	1	Uca leptostyla	.	text p. 182	location	Antigua, Antigua and Barbuda	.	burgersi	>MSR	A strange typo mixing up multiple names. The author refers to figures from Rathbun (1918) and was clearly not attempting to create a new name. While geographically, it could be a reference to {{leptodactyla}}, Rathbun (1921) later identifies a few specimens from the same expedition as {{mordax}}, although we now know that the correct identification for Rathbun's specimens should be {{burgersi}}.	.

Ng2008	18.5	Uca (Gelasimus) vocans	.	text p. 157, 240, 243	citation	Say1817	1	=	=	Reference to <em class="species">Ocypode citharoedicus.</em> This is an erroneous interpretaion of Say, on two counts. First, the species Say refers to is clearly meant to be the American species {{pugilator}} and not {{vocans}}. Second, he never actually proposes the name <em class="species">Ocypode citharoedicus.</em> He mentions that he had planned on using that name until he realized the species had already been described. 	.
